KOLLAM

Kollam

is a district in the south-western part of Kerala that offers a variety of attractions for tourists. It is a place where you can enjoy the natural beauty, the historical heritage, and the cultural diversity of Kerala. Here are some of the tourist attractions in Kollam district that you can visit:

Ashtamudi Backwaters

This is one of the main attractions in Kollam, and the second largest lake in Kerala. The lake has eight branches, hence the name Ashtamudi, which means “eight cones”. The lake is connected to the Arabian Sea by the Neendakara estuary, and offers a scenic and relaxing experience. You can enjoy a cruise on a traditional houseboat, or a kettuvallam, and witness the rural life, lush greenery, and diverse wildlife along the banks. You can also visit the nearby islands, such as Munroe Island, Chavara Island, and Alumkadavu Island

Jatayu Earths Center

This is a rock-themed park and a cultural centre, built on a hilltop, near Chadayamangalam village. The park is named after Jatayu, the mythical bird from Ramayana, who tried to rescue Sita from Ravana. The park has the world’s largest bird sculpture, which is 200 feet long, 150 feet wide, and 70 feet high. The park also has various attractions, such as a 6D theatre, a cable car, an adventure zone, a museum, and a healing centre

Palaruvi Waterfall

This is a scenic and serene waterfall located near Aryankavu, on the Kollam-Shencottah road. The name of the waterfall means “the stream of milk”, and the waterfall is about 300 feet high. The waterfall is surrounded by dense forest, and has medicinal properties. It is a great spot for swimming, picnicking, and relaxing

Thangassery Light House

This is one of the oldest and famous lighthouses in Kerala, built by the British in 1902. It is situated on the Thangassery beach, and offers a panoramic view of the Arabian Sea and the Kollam city. The lighthouse is 144 feet high, and has 193 steps to reach the top. The lighthouse is open to visitors from 3:30 pm to 5:30 pm
